text: Who identifies himself as the primary author at the beginning of the letter to Philemon?
verseText: Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother, To Philemon our beloved fellow worker

text: Based on the author's self-description as a 'prisoner for Christ Jesus', Philemon is often categorized with which group of his letters?
verseText: Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus... I, Paul, an old man and now a prisoner also for Christ Jesus— (Along with Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, it was likely written during Paul's imprisonment).

text: Who is named as the primary recipient of the letter?
verseText: To Philemon our beloved fellow worker

text: What was the legal and social status of Onesimus in relation to Philemon before he ran away?
verseText: For this perhaps is why he was parted from you for a while, that you might have him back forever, no longer as a slave but more than a slave, as a beloved brother...

text: What significant life change occurred for Onesimus while he was away from Philemon and encountered Paul?
options: He was arrested by Roman authorities
He became a follower of Christ
verseText: I appeal to you for my child, Onesimus, whose father I became in my imprisonment.

text: What is the central request Paul makes of Philemon in this personal letter?
options: To publicly condemn the practice of slavery
To send financial support for Paul's ministry
To welcome Onesimus back, not as property, but as a brother in Christ
To provide instructions on church discipline
verseText: no longer as a slave but more than a slave, as a beloved brother—specially to me, but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord. So if you consider me your partner, receive him as you would receive me.

text: Rather than using his apostolic authority, on what basis does Paul primarily make his appeal to Philemon?
options: Love and their shared faith partnership
verseText: Accordingly, though I am bold enough in Christ to command you to do what is required, yet for love's sake I prefer to appeal to you—I, Paul... So if you consider me your partner, receive him as you would receive me.

text: What personal responsibility does Paul offer to take regarding any wrong Onesimus committed against Philemon?
options: He asks the church in Colossae to cover the cost
He tells Philemon it should be forgiven
He offers to pay any debt himself, charging it to his own account
He suggests Onesimus work longer hours to repay it
verseText: If he has wronged you at all, or owes you anything, charge that to my account. I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay it—to say nothing of your owing me even your own self.

text: Paul uses a play on Onesimus' name (meaning 'useful'). How does he describe Onesimus' transformation in terms of usefulness?
options: He is now useful to both Philemon and Paul
He is useful only to Paul
verseText: (Formerly he was useless to you, but now he is indeed useful to you and to me.) (This is a play on Onesimus' name, which means 'useful').

text: This intensely personal letter serves as a powerful illustration of how the gospel impacts and transforms what aspect of life?
verseText: (The gospel changes the master-slave relationship into a brotherhood in Christ).

text: Who joins Paul in sending greetings at the very beginning of the letter?
verseText: Paul, a prisoner for Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother...

text: Besides Philemon, who else is specifically named in the opening greeting?
options: Apphia, Archippus, and the church in Philemon's house
verseText: To Philemon our beloved fellow worker and Apphia our sister and Archippus our fellow soldier, and the church in your house:

text: What relationship is suggested for Apphia in the greeting?
options: A church leader from another city
verseText: and Apphia our sister...

text: Who is referred to as 'our fellow soldier' in the greeting?
verseText: and Archippus our fellow soldier...

text: Where did the church associated with Philemon meet?
verseText: ...and the church in your house:

text: What two qualities in Philemon does Paul mention he gives thanks for?
options: His love and faith toward the Lord Jesus and all the saints
His leadership skills and speaking ability
verseText: I thank my God always when I remember you in my prayers, because I hear of your love and of the faith that you have toward the Lord Jesus and for all the saints,

text: What does Paul pray Philemon's 'sharing of his faith' will become?
options: Effective for the full knowledge of every good thing in Christ
verseText: and I pray that the sharing of your faith may become effective for the full knowledge of every good thing that is in us for the sake of Christ.

text: What effect did Philemon's love have on Paul and the saints?
options: It brought much joy and comfort, refreshing the hearts of the saints
verseText: For I have derived much joy and comfort from your love, my brother, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed through you.

text: Paul mentions he could be bold and command Philemon. What status gives him this potential authority?
verseText: Accordingly, though I am bold enough in Christ to command you to do what is required,

text: Instead of commanding, Paul appeals 'for love's sake'. What two personal circumstances does he mention to support this appeal?
verseText: yet for love's sake I prefer to appeal to you—I, Paul, an old man and now a prisoner also for Christ Jesus—

text: How does Paul affectionately refer to Onesimus when appealing for him?
options: My child, whose father I became in my imprisonment
verseText: I appeal to you for my child, Onesimus, whose father I became in my imprisonment.

text: Paul expresses a desire to keep Onesimus with him. For what purpose?
options: To serve Paul in his imprisonment, on Philemon's behalf
To send him on a mission trip
To train him as a church leader
verseText: I would have been glad to keep him with me, in order that he might serve me on your behalf during my imprisonment for the gospel,

text: Why did Paul decide to send Onesimus back instead of keeping him?
options: Paul didn't need his help anymore
He didn't want to do anything without Philemon's consent
verseText: but I preferred to do nothing without your consent in order that your goodness might not be by compulsion but of your own accord.

text: Paul suggests a possible providential reason for Onesimus' temporary departure. What is it?
options: So Philemon could get a better slave
So Philemon might have him back forever, not as a slave but a brother
verseText: For this perhaps is why he was parted from you for a while, that you might have him back forever, no longer as a slave but more than a slave, as a beloved brother...

text: In what two spheres does Paul emphasize Onesimus is now Philemon's brother?
options: Both in the flesh and in the Lord
In the church and in the community
verseText: ...specially to me, but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord.

text: On what basis does Paul ask Philemon to 'receive him as you would receive me'?
options: If Philemon wants to be repaid
If Philemon considers Paul his partner
verseText: So if you consider me your partner, receive him as you would receive me.

text: When Paul offers to repay Onesimus' debt, what does he gently remind Philemon that Philemon owes Paul?
options: Even his own self (likely referring to his conversion)
verseText: I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay it—to say nothing of your owing me even your own self.

text: What benefit does Paul hope to receive from Philemon in the Lord?
verseText: Yes, brother, I want some benefit from you in the Lord. Refresh my heart in Christ.

text: How confident is Paul that Philemon will respond positively?
options: He is confident in Philemon's obedience, expecting he'll do even more than asked
verseText: Confident of your obedience, I write to you, knowing that you will do even more than I say.

text: What additional request does Paul make of Philemon, indicating his hope for release from prison?
options: To prepare a guest room for him
To write a letter to the authorities
verseText: At the same time, prepare a guest room for me, for I am hoping that through your prayers I will be graciously given to you.

text: Who does Paul mention sends greetings alongside him at the end of the letter?
options: Epaphras, Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke
verseText: Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends greetings to you, and so do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers.

text: What relationship is suggested for Apphia in the greeting, often assumed due to the context of a house church?
options: A church leader from another city
verseText: and Apphia our sister...

text: Who is referred to as 'our fellow soldier' in the greeting, possibly indicating a role in spiritual warfare or ministry leadership?
verseText: and Archippus our fellow soldier...

text: Where did the church associated with Philemon meet, indicating the common practice of early Christian gatherings?
verseText: ...and the church in your house:

text: What two qualities in Philemon does Paul specifically mention he gives thanks for when praying?
options: His love and faith toward the Lord Jesus and all the saints
His leadership skills and speaking ability
verseText: I thank my God always when I remember you in my prayers, because I hear of your love and of the faith that you have toward the Lord Jesus and for all the saints,

text: Paul prays that the 'sharing' or 'fellowship' of Philemon's faith may become effective. What outcome does he desire from this?
options: The full knowledge of every good thing that is in us for Christ's sake
verseText: and I pray that the sharing of your faith may become effective for the full knowledge of every good thing that is in us for the sake of Christ.

text: What positive impact did Philemon's love have on Paul and other believers?
options: It brought much joy and comfort, refreshing the hearts of the saints
verseText: For I have derived much joy and comfort from your love, my brother, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed through you.

text: Paul mentions he could command Philemon to do what is required. What gives him this potential authority?
verseText: Accordingly, though I am bold enough in Christ to command you to do what is required,

text: Instead of commanding, Paul appeals 'for love's sake'. What two personal circumstances does he highlight to strengthen this appeal?
options: His status as an old man and a prisoner for Christ
verseText: yet for love's sake I prefer to appeal to you—I, Paul, an old man and now a prisoner also for Christ Jesus—

text: How does Paul describe his relationship with Onesimus, emphasizing the spiritual transformation that occurred?
options: My child, whose father I became in my imprisonment
verseText: I appeal to you for my child, Onesimus, whose father I became in my imprisonment.

text: Paul wished he could have kept Onesimus with him. In what capacity would Onesimus have served Paul?
options: To serve Paul on Philemon's behalf during his imprisonment
As a messenger to other churches
verseText: I would have been glad to keep him with me, in order that he might serve me on your behalf during my imprisonment for the gospel,

text: Why did Paul ultimately decide against keeping Onesimus without first contacting Philemon?
options: He wanted Philemon's consent so his goodness would be voluntary, not forced
verseText: but I preferred to do nothing without your consent in order that your goodness might not be by compulsion but of your own accord.

text: Paul suggests a possible divine purpose behind Onesimus' temporary separation from Philemon. What was this potential purpose?
options: So Onesimus could experience the world
So Philemon might receive him back forever, no longer as a slave but as a beloved brother
verseText: For this perhaps is why he was parted from you for a while, that you might have him back forever, no longer as a slave but more than a slave, as a beloved brother...

text: Paul emphasizes the new relationship between Philemon and Onesimus exists in two realms. What are they?
options: Both in the flesh (human relationship) and in the Lord (spiritual relationship)
verseText: ...specially to me, but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord.

text: Paul urges Philemon to receive Onesimus as he would receive Paul himself. What condition does he attach to this request?
options: If Philemon considers Paul his partner
verseText: So if you consider me your partner, receive him as you would receive me.

text: When Paul offers to personally cover any debt Onesimus owes, what significant debt does he gently remind Philemon about?
options: That Philemon owes Paul his very self (likely referring to his conversion)
verseText: I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay it—to say nothing of your owing me even your own self.

text: What specific benefit or outcome does Paul desire from Philemon's positive response to his appeal?
options: That his (Paul's) heart may be refreshed in Christ
verseText: Yes, brother, I want some benefit from you in the Lord. Refresh my heart in Christ.

text: How does Paul express his expectation regarding Philemon's response?
options: He is confident Philemon will obey and even do more than asked
verseText: Confident of your obedience, I write to you, knowing that you will do even more than I say.

text: What practical request does Paul make that indicates his hope of being released from prison soon?
options: To prepare a guest room for him
To send news of the church
verseText: At the same time, prepare a guest room for me, for I am hoping that through your prayers I will be graciously given to you.

text: Who does Paul identify as his 'fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus' sending greetings?
verseText: Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends greetings to you,

text: Which individuals, also mentioned in Colossians, does Paul list as his 'fellow workers' sending greetings?
verseText: and so do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers.

text: What is the final blessing Paul offers at the very end of the letter?
options: May you have peace and prosperity.
May the Lord bless your household.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.
May you be filled with wisdom.
verseText: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

text: What common Pauline greeting appears near the beginning of the letter?
options: 'Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ'
'Mercy, peace, and love be multiplied to you'
verseText: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

text: How does Paul refer to Philemon in the opening verse, indicating their relationship in ministry?
verseText: To Philemon our beloved fellow worker

text: The letter to Philemon provides a practical application of which core Christian principle?
verseText: (The entire letter deals with the reconciliation between Philemon and Onesimus based on their shared faith in Christ).

text: What is the significance of Paul stating, 'I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay it'?
options: It served as a legally binding personal guarantee
It was merely a figure of speech
verseText: I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay it...

text: Given the names mentioned (Archippus, Onesimus, Epaphras, Mark, etc.), Philemon likely lived in or near which city?
verseText: (Many of the same individuals are mentioned in the letter to the Colossians, suggesting geographical proximity).

text: What does Paul's approach in this letter demonstrate about handling sensitive interpersonal conflicts within the Christian community?
options: The preference for appeal based on love and relationship over command
The importance of ignoring minor issues
verseText: (Paul chooses appeal over command, emphasizing love and partnership).
